title: The Awakening of the Forest

thumbnail.alt_text: Forest filled with dozens of mostly nude women and men.

description: Paul Delvaux painted The Awakening of the Forest in the late 1930s, after having adopted Surrealism as a visual language to give form to his inner world—one populated with childhood memories and fantasy. For this monumental painting, the artist transformed an episode from Jules Verne’s Journey to the Center of the Earth (1864), in which Professor Otto Lidenbrock and his nephew Axel discover a prehistoric forest deep inside the earth. Delvaux showed the professor at left, examining a rock or fossil; behind him stands Axel, who bears a striking resemblance to the artist himself. Under a full moon, a group of women in the background appear like automatons. In the foreground, several figures combine human and vegetal elements; these ambiguous figures seem to embody a primordial, as yet undifferentiated, state. A woman in the right foreground and another in the left middle ground, both in Victorian dress, hold lamps and try in a vain to shed light on the unyielding mystery of the scene. Despite the multitude of naked figures and their detailed description, The Awakening of the Forest retains a detachment that adds to its strange and mysterious effect.
publication_history:
M. Fryns, “Plus-value spectaculaire pour les Belges,” Les Beaux-Arts (May 1, 1959) no. 854, p. 4.

Paul Aloise de Bock, Paul Delvaux (Brussels, 1967), p. 290, pl. 36.

A. Fermigier, “Exposition. Explorateurs de l’imaginaire. Des peintres que l’injustice de l’histoire et les frontiers culturelles nous avaient longtemps un peu dissimulés,” Le Nouvel Observateur (February 1972), no. 379, p. 45.

José Vovelle, Le Surrealisme en Belgique, (Brussels, 1972), p. 270.

P. A. Touttain, “Du Voyage au Centre de la Terre aux Phases de la Lune (A propos d’une letter de Paul Delvaux),” Cashier de l’Herne (1974) no. 25, pp. 105 and 107.

Michel Butor, Jean Clair and Suzanne Houbart-Wilkin, Delvaux : Catalogue de l’Oeuvre peint (Brusssels, 1975), no. 99, p. 184 and pp. 78–80 (ill).
exhibition_history:
Brussels, Palais des Beaux-Arts, Paul Delvaux, February 1940, no. 1.

Brussels, Palais des Beaux-Arts, Paul Delvaux, December 1944–January 1945, no. 9.

Brussels, Galerie Georges Giroux, April 1925, no. 49. 

Paris, Grand Palais, Peintres de l’imaginaire, Symbolistes et surréalistes belges, February–April 1972, no. 86 (ill.).

Rotterdam, Museum Boymans-van Beuningen, Paul Delvaux, April–June 1973, no. 18 (ill.).

Knokke-Heist, Casino, Paul Delvaux, June–September 1973, no. 11 (ill.).

Paris, Galerie Isy Brachot, Paul Delvaux, November 1991–February 7, 1992.
provenance_text: Camille Goemans, Brussels, by April 1959.  Mme. G. Plouvier-Warland, Antwerp, 1959-possibly 1982.  Purchased by Art Institute, 1991.
